urn:contentItem:5R7G-FH81-DY0W-40PR-00000-00$1.5 Trillion Tax Cut Bill, Taxpayers Expected To See Paycheck Changes In February; Trump On Tax Bill, Results Will Speak For Themselves;2017-12-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:07:03ZLexisNexis$1.5 Trillion Tax Cut Bill, Taxpayers Expected To See Paycheck Changes In February; Trump On Tax Bill, Results Will Speak For Themselves;LanhamFULL TEXT

LAURA INGRAHAM, FOX NEWS CHANNEL HOST: To Chuck Schumer and Nancy Pelosi, through all of this, I'm reminded of this great holiday classic. Do you guys know that bumbles bounce right now? Shannon Bream, take it away.

SHANNON BREAM, FOX NEWS CHANNEL HOST: We got serious things to talk about Laura. How can I not laugh at that? It's goofy. All right, thank you very much. Here's what's coming up on our show tonight.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Merry Christmas America.

BREAM: ObamaCare's individual mandate repealed, $1.5 trillion in tax cuts, companies already responding, so why are critics saying bah humbug?

REP. JACKIE SPEIER (D), CALIFORNIA: A lump of coal into your Christmas stocking.

SEN. CHUCK SCHUMER (D-NY), SENATE MINORITY LEADER: The economy is not going to take off.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: The ugliest display of pigs at the

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Are you living in a fantasy world?

BREAM: Will downplaying historic tax cuts backfire on the President's critics? We'll debate.

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: It's always a lot of fun when you win.

BREAM: Plus, the Obama administration, the former Head of the DNC, Hezbollah, and some shady I.T. workers on Capitol Hill and a reported possible connection.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: This was a classic money laundering operation.

BREAM: We investigate another bombshell report with Congressman Ron DeSantis. And he once said that President Trump was a menace to conservatism. Rich Lowry explains why some never Trumpers are now partying with the President.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BREAM: Hello and welcome to FOX NEWS @NIGHT, I'm Shannon Bream in Washington. New tonight, as the most sweeping changes to the tax code in more than 30 years make their way to the President's desk, we're learning about new challenges to the $1.5 trillion tax cuts and new indications it's already having a positive impact. First those challenges. Blue states like California, New York, and New Jersey are already looking at taking legal action trying to stop tax reform before it becomes law. The bill hits those states hardest with high incomes, high property values and high state and local taxes. For example, Bloomberg reporting tonight about this effect on Wall Street, "One trader sipping a Bloody Mary on a morning flight to somewhere more tropical said he's going to stop registering as a Republican." New Jersey Governor-elect Democrat Phil Murphy says "everything is on the table including challenging the constitutionality of the bill.

PHIL MURPHY (D), GOVERNOR-ELECT, NEW JERSEY: It's many thousands of dollars Carl and this is an awful bill for America, it's an awful day for America and it certainly is an awful bill for New Jersey. We're going to have to fight back.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BREAM: Well, they're going to have to move fast because here are the pluses. One sign, taxpayers across the nation will likely see the first changes to their tax and their pay holding -- paycheck holdings as soon as February. Also, several major companies announcing their workers will see some of the tax windfalls from cutting the corporate tax rate from 21 percent to -- from 35 percent including big bonuses for workers in some cases. Democrats calling it all a public relations stunt, "a fraction of the bounty" as one media report puts it. Things are moving fast here in Washington so we've got team coverage tonight. Ellison Barber has the latest on the next big fight which is keeping the government open past the Friday deadline. And Chief National Correspondent Ed Henry is covering the development since the President and Republicans celebrated their legislative victory. So, Ed, we begin with you. Good evening.

ED HENRY, FOX NEWS CHANNEL, CHIEF NATIONAL CORRESPONDENT: Well, Shannon, I haven't seen any Bloody Marys around here at the White House tonight but I can tell you remembering the campaign, President Trump promised that Americans would get tired of all the winning. And while to be sure, he has a long way to go before he can say that he's enacted a large share of his agenda. He is claiming momentum tonight that just a few short weeks or even months ago would've seemed impossible.

Take a look at this pep rally he had on the south lawn in addition to the last cabinet meeting, the last cabinet meeting of the year where he was touting various successes. He had Republican Leaders like Paul Ryan and Mitch McConnell on board. Remember, after the failure of repeal and replace, the President mocked McConnell on Twitter and left the door open to another Republican taking the Majority Leader post. Tonight here's the big picture is tax cuts that could supercharge an economy taking off. Thanks in part to massive cuts the government regulations have already taken place. The tax bill also includes ANWR. That means opening the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to energy exploration. That's decades in the making. If it we're standalone bill, it would be massive in and of itself. There's also a major initiative on health care.

They eliminated the individual mandate in ObamaCare. It is not repeal and replace but it is a major pushing back on the signature domestic achievement of the President's predecessor. The President also at that cabinet meeting today touting the fact that ISIS is on the run, something that he promised in the campaign to much skepticism, also touting the confirmation of Supreme Court Justice Neil Gorsuch plus a record number of Circuit Court Judicial Nominees that have been confirmed. Not a single Democrat though voted for this tax package. So if it succeeds, they'll have a hard time explaining it in the midterm elections. But Democrats have been consistent about charging this will cost too much money. It will add a lot to the debt, and perhaps the most prominent talking point of all has been that the corporate tax cut they say will not trickle down the workers. Listen to Chuck Schumer.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SCHUMER: At&T, a big American company, a fine American company. They are tax rate over the last ten years was a mere eight percent and they cut 80,000 jobs. That one statistic belies all of this trickle-down bunk.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

HENRY: Yet, just a couple of hours later, At&T announced it will pay yes, a special $1,000 bonus to more than200,000 of their employees trickling down. Today Boeing announced $300 million in employee-related investments. Fifth Third Bank Corp. announced plans to raise its minimum hourly wage for all employees. All employees to $15 and distribute yes a one-time bonus of $1000 because of the tax cut. Wells Fargo saying its pay rate will go up to $15 and they're pledging next year $400 million in charitable contributions as well. All reasons why some of the President's advisor tonight are telling me they want to pivot out of this victory on tax cuts to infrastructure, immigration information reform, other big issues. And there's pro-Trump non-profit group America first policies is now planning $1 million T.V. ad blitz that will start on Christmas Day, but in fact, they're giving FOX NEWS @NIGHT a first look. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Thank you for cutting my taxes.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Thank you for fixing our economy.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Thank you for keeping my family safe.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Thank you for putting America first.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Thank you for supporting Israel.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: As veterans, thank you for reminding us to stand for our National Anthem.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Thank you, President Trump.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Thank you, President Trump, for letting us a Merry Christmas again.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

HENRY: And we mention that riff with Senator Mitch McConnell, they were all smiles in the Oval Office today. The Kentucky Senator bringing yes, a Louisville slugger from his home state to give to the President after this tax cut victory. Clearly, they are trying to pivot out of this to other victories. Although there are still a lot of challenges heading into the New Year for this President including yes, the Special Counsel investigation by Robert Mueller, Shannon.

BREAM: All right. What a difference a big legislative win makes. Ed Henry at the White House, thank you so much, Ed. All right, as President Trump and the GOP celebrate a big win on the tax bill, they do face a very new challenge getting Democrats on board with a funding measure to keep the government going past midnight Friday. The clock is ticking and loudly. Ellison Barber joins us now with more on that looming battle. Good evening Ellison.

ELLISON BARBER, FOX NEWS CHANNEL CORRESPONDENT: Good evening Shannon. Republican Leaders and the White House say a shutdown is absolutely not going to happen. Behind the scenes though, rank-and-file Republicans do not seem as optimistic. Utah Congressman Chris Stewart told one of our producers that this, the continuing resolution, would never be as easy as party leaders expected. He also said, "we need to do a better job multitasking." Republicans met at 5:00 this evening and talked for an hour, trying to find a way to move ahead.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Do you have a plan?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I think there's a number of different factors. There's you know, do you do separate bills, do you put them all together? You know, the coalition of supplemental versus 702 reauthorizations.

REP. DAVE BRAT (R), VIRGINIA: There are some disparate needs in terms of defense (INAUDIBLE) right? I want get defense right.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I'm optimistic we can get there. We're not there yet.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARBER: Republicans tested the waters among their party tonight with two options. One, an interim bill that funds the government at current levels through mid-January and includes defense anomalies or bumps that increase spending, renewal of the controversial domestic spying FISA program, and some assistance for children's health insurance. The second, a stand-alone $81 billion supplemental disaster spending bill for hurricane damage in places Puerto Rico and Texas and the wildfires in California. Some say Republicans waited too long to do all of this and spent too much time focusing on the tax bill.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SCHUMER: The bottom line is we haven't even seen anything. They're so busy with the tax proposal that we haven't even seen a proposal.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARBER: House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi sent this note to Democrats earlier today urging a No vote on the C.R. It says in part, "Democrats want to see funding for opioids, veterans pensions, and support for the DREAM Act which would clarify the legal status for hundreds of thousands of immigrants." She also writes "unless we see respect for our values and priorities, we continue to urge a strong No on the continuing resolution." Now here's what some House Democrats said last week.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JOSEPH CROWLEY (D), NEW YORK: The question really is as to whether we will have that leverage. We believe when we are discussing a spending package for next year that they will need our votes to pass it. And when they do, they will need to talk to us about what our priorities are which includes DACA, which includes CHIP, which includes community health sentence, which includes opioids.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARBER: Republican celebrated a major political win this afternoon, a little doubt about that. But now the question seems to be will the Republicans in Congress negate that win in less than 48 hours by failing to prevent a shutdown and sending thousands of government workers home for Christmas without a paycheck. Shannon?

BREAM: All right, we'll keep an eye on it as it plays out. Ellison Barber, thank you very much. Will Democrats find themselves in a conundrum tonight having to fight a measure that hits wealthier blue states hard but according to even critics will give 80 percent of Americans a nice tax cut? That means they have to downplay a $1.5 trillion overall tax cut. Here's how President Trump feels about that.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: Unfortunately the Democrats don't like to see tax cutting. They like to see tax increases and they like to complain.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BREAM: All right former Chief of Staff for West Virginia Senator Joe Manchin, Chris Kofinis, and the t Matt Schlapp, the President of the American Conservative Union join us now to discuss. Good to see you both gentleman.

MATT SCHLAPP, PRESIDENT, AMERICAN CONSERVATIVE UNION: Good to see you, Shannon.

BREAM: Ok, I want to play a sound bite from Democrat Congresswoman Jackie Speier. Here's what she says about this bill that just got passed and celebrated today.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SPEIER: So what we're doing here today is basically saying wealthy Americans, big fat Christmas present for you. Tiny Tim, we're taking your crutch away from you and all the other kids in this country. And we're putting a lump of coal into your Christmas stocking.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BREAM: All right, Matt, so no crutches, just lumps of coal.

SCHLAPP: You got to pick a metaphor in politics Shannon. You got to pick one and go with it. Coal, a crutch, look, I think the Democrats are on very thin ice. The President is talking about allowing working people to keep more of the money they work hard to earn. He's going to move to infrastructure which is bridges and roads which we all use. And then he's going to want to reinstate the idea that the states to put a work requirement on welfare reform. This resistance to everything in the Trump agenda might work for a lot of Democrats but it doesn't work for those key Democrats up in more purple districts especially those Senators.

BREAM: Yes, but they didn't vote yes on this tax bill.

SCHLAPP: That's exactly right. They are starting off by saying were not going to agree with anything on the Trump agenda and it's dicey politics, especially on issues that in the end are going to be very popular, including a growing economy.

BREAM: Well, Chris, they must feel emboldened that they didn't need to vote for this. I mean, they feel like it was the right stand for them to take.

CHRIS KOFINIS, FORMER CHIEF OF STAFF, JOE MANCHIN: Well, I think you look at for example what's happened in Alabama, what's happened in Virginia, two states that are traditionally pretty strong, to say the least for Republicans that they haven't done very well.

BREAM: I would argue that Virginia, where I live is very purple this days.

KOFINIS: Yes, but you know, this was a -- you know, when you have an incumbent, usually you'll have a switch. But putting it aside I think when talk about the tax bill, what's interesting to me is this whole argument about somehow Democrats opposed to tax cuts. That actually is not true. Democrats are opposed to tax cuts to benefit an incredibly small percentage of the population.

BREAM: 80 percent of Americans is a small percentage?

KOFINIS: Yes, but where's -- the disproportionate amount of -- the money is going at the top and it's going for corporations.

BREAM: 80 percent are getting -- this is from Tax Policy Center which is - - they're (INAUDIBLE) you know that. I mean, they say 80 percent get a cut, 15 percent no change, five percent will probably get a raise and a lot of us is going to be wealthy people.

KOFINIS: But if you're going to have $1.5 trillion tax cut, don't you think the overall majority should go to the middle the middle class? Do you really think that people who are --

BREAM: 800 percent of Americans.

KOFINIS: But my point is, do you really -- did anyone really think that people who are billionaires or corporations are struggling right now? Corporate profits are at a record level, right? We all know that. Now, you want to -- you want to reduce corporate taxes, great but how do you reduce corporate taxes and with the same face and the same voice I should turn around and say you care about the deficit. You can't have it both ways.

SCHLAPP: I reject -- I reject this idea that the Democrats actually care about the deficit when Barack Obama spent more in eight years than all the presidents before him. And I reject this notion that we shouldn't do everything possible to increase economic growth so that American could have greater economic prosperity.

KOFINIS: Wait. Wait -- but Matt --

BREAM: I just -- I just want to put this up real quick. This is something that Ed had in his package. I think we have it too as well about the different companies that today announced they're going to be giving bonuses, they're going to be pouring money back into their workers and employees. There were a number of big corporations. You can see in there. Comcast, Wells Fargo, AT&T, I mean, these are big names Chris of companies that said great, we've got this. Now, a lot of you are going to get bonuses or we're going to -- in other words benefit our employees.

KOFINIS: Listen, I'm the happiest when anyone gets a raise. There's no question about that.

BREAM: You work for (INAUDIBLE)?

KOFINIS: No I do not. No, I don't. But if you look at for example the history of major tax cuts, the Reagan tax cuts, the Bush Jr. tax cuts, right, both during all those -- both during those big significant tax cuts, if you look at where wages have been for income for workers, they've been stagnant. For the last three decades, wages have been stagnant.

SCHLAPP: That's not right.

KOFINIS: It is right. That is --

SCHLAPP: That is not right. And the evidence --

KOFINIS: It is right.

SCHLAPP: And the other thing -- and the other thing -- the one thing about all those previous tax cuts is you had significant number of Democrats that put the country's interest over their parties interests and they actually did what was right for the economy.

BREAM: I mean, in 1986, the last big one of these was bipartisan. But there are Democrats that you know, who say this time around Republicans made it impossible for them to come along.

SCHLAPP: And that's because they say it was done on reconciliation. They make it sound like reconciliation is a Republican only.

BREAM: Well, that is how we got healthcare.

SCHLAPP: And that is wrong. The fact is the system is all kinds of reconciliation measures in the past that have been bipartisan. There's no reason why the Democrats --and if Chris says the Democrats want to cut taxes. What's the name of the bill? I haven't seen the bill.

KOFINIS: So here's one thing. I can -- I can -- just use my former boss as a perfect example. When you're talking about you know, a Democrat from a pretty reddish state as of late.

SCHLAPP: He turned red.

KOFINIS: Yes, to say the least.

SCHLAPP: He's been a little bit of double for them.

KOFINIS: Well, I mean, let's -- well, let's focus on the tax cut. And he's not in trouble. He's won every -- you know, every race.

BREAM: He's very well loved. I cover -- I'm covering history ---

(CROSSTALK)

BREAM: We are talking about Joe Manchin by the way in West Virginia and I covered that race and he's very well loved on both sides.

KOFINIS: Senator Manchin was very open to tax cuts. He met with the administration. He met with the President. There were discussions about it. And they -- and Mitch McConnell and the Senate Republicans and Senate Leadership and others shut the door down. And it is right. It is right.

SCHLAPP: No that's not right. Let me jump in there. Let me jump in --

KOFINIS: He said that himself.

BREAM: We have to wrap it up.

SCHLAPP: He said that he want a 25 percent income tax rate for corporations. That is out of step with where the world is. American jobs, American companies are leaving America since our rating are too high.

KOFINIS: No but if you want to -- if you want to create -- if you want to create jobs -- if you want to create jobs, it actually benefit the middle class.

BREAM: Wrap it up.

SCHLAPP: There you go.

BREAM: Well, and the thing is I mean, we got to -- we got to see how the GOP now sells it because before the midterm, they have to convince Americans that by the time they get their tax bill April of 2019, that this is going to benefit them. So they've got a job to do on that. Chris remains unconvinced.

KOFINIS: Well, if you look at the polls, they're right.

BREAM: OK, goodbye. Good to see you both. Thanks for coming in.

All right, the Deputy Director of the FBI Andrew McCabe will have a closed- door transcribed interview tomorrow with two Congressional Committees. Now the Justice Department though has sent a letter today to the House Judiciary and House Oversight Committee stating that McCabe will not be allowed to discuss anything related to Mueller's Russia investigation. Congressional Investigators tell Fox News that yesterday is seven-hour interrogation of McCabe presented conflicts with the testimony of previous witnesses. And now, that is prompting the House Intelligence Committee to potentially issue new subpoenas next week for FBI and Justice Department personnel renewing speculation that demoted Justice Department official Bruce Ohr, the one who is talking with Fusion GPS, he may be among those summoned for testimony.

Well, a new twist in the case of an illegal immigrant teen seeking an abortion here in the U.S. Congresswoman Marsha Blackburn response to the latest turn in the legal battle over young illegals in the U.S. and abortion. And a Member of Congress demands answers after a report that a Congressional I.T. staffer (INAUDIBLE) by a leading Democrat may have been laundering money for Hezbollah through a phony car dealership. That's ahead. Plus, joining the party, what's the status of the never-Trump movement after today's big win for the President? Stick around and see how they're feeling.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BREAM: Homeland Security releasing a pregnant 19-year-old illegal immigrant who lied about her age, now freeing the government from any obligation to facilitate her abortion. According to The Washington Times, the illegal immigrant identified by the pseudo name Jane Roe falsely claimed to be 17 when she was arrested at the U.S.-Mexico border so she would be eligible for a lenient treatment. The feds say they released her on her own terms so her anticipated abortion would not have to be facilitated by the U.S. government. Well, President Trump promising to get even tougher on immigration, pledging to do away with the primary ways that people come here from other countries.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: We will get rid of chain migration and the Visa Lottery Program. We have a lottery program where we take in a lottery people from other countries. In some places, we are bringing in some very bad, bad people.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BREAM: So how is Congress responding to those calls from the President? GOP Congresswoman Marsha Blackburn of Tennessee joins us now. great to have you with us today.

REP. MARSHA BLACKBURN (R), TENNESSEE: Great to be with you.

BREAM: OK, how is Congress going to tackle this? Will there be any bipartisan movement on this big issue?

BLACKBURN: I would hope that there would be. The Raise Act is something that would address the lottery and the chain migration issues. And this is one of the things that we know. It's time to move to a merit-based system. Canada uses it. This is something that we should do. We are a country that recognizes merit. So let's move to that.

BREAM: OK, well, the archbishop of Miami. I want to play or put up a little bit of a quote that we have from him. What he says about this and the fact that we need to move forward. He says "derisive comments on chain migration forget that a foundational principle of our immigration law has long been to reunite families." He says that's a principle that we worked on. But this principle has been seriously eroded in recent years and administration officials seem to be poised to make it worse.

BLACKBURN: No, they're going to clean the system up. It is time to make certain that we change the way people come here. And look at what recently happened in New York. The last two occurrences there, the Visa Lottery and chain migration. So let's stop it. We know where this is happening, but we know where the weaknesses are, the vulnerabilities are. And we also know that it's a fairness issue. Move to a merit system. Set up a points system. And then let's make certain that we are bringing the best of the best that are wanting to come in and that we are ending this process of chain migration.

BREAM: Let me ask you on this other illegal -- legal immigrant story that we've been covering right before this about this -- these growing number of legal cases that we see where underage teenagers are coming across the border and seeking abortions here in the U.S. The ACLU was mounting a larger legal assault on that and say they want to make sure these women who are here have access to abortion even if they're underage.

BLACKBURN: And this is one of those things where we have to say they're here illegally. They are not entitled to the services, and it's inappropriate. And when I talk to my constituents in Tennessee, they talk about this as fairness. We do not use taxpayer dollars to fund abortion. And they don't want it to take place with those that are here illegally.

BREAM: In the last case I know that we had, there were some confusion about who was funding the abortion, the case that happens in October. Her attorneys said that there was somebody stepping up to help with the funding. We never really got a clear answer on that. I also want to ask you about you chaired a year the select panel that looked into Planned Parenthood, whether or not they were trafficking it all in body parts of aborted fetuses. And now you have news that the DOJ and FBI are investigating based on what you found.

BLACKBURN: That's exactly right. Our panel did a tremendous amount of work. We did 15 criminal referrals, 11 to States Attorney General and four were to federal, to DOJ. And then we found out that between DOJ and the FBI, they taking up all 15. And looking at what has transpired between the abortion clinics and these third-party sellers of the baby body parts. So we're pleased that that investigation is moving forward.

BREAM: Well, Planned Parenthood as you know, has denied any wrongdoing, any criminal wrongdoing in the case so we'll watch and see how these cases proceed.

BLACKBURN: Absolutely.

BREAM: Thank you very much for coming tonight.

BLACKBURN: Thank you.

BREAM: Merry Christmas.

BLACKBURN: And to you too.

BREAM: All right, Silicon Valley could win big under the tax cut plan. Stick around for reaction from leading liberal like Mark Zuckerberg and the Google guy. And trouble for Matt Damon at the premiere of his new movie. Details on that just ahead.

SHANNON BREAM, FOX NEWS HOST: A busy night in Hollywood, Matt Damon did not show up for the L.A. premiere of his new movie, Downsizing. Apparent, Matt rep. said it was because his dealing with an ongoing family matter. But the Hollywood Reporter says many believe he didn't show because of his recent comments over the current sexual harassment controversy. Damon has said, he believes the culture of outrage needs to recognize that there is a spectrum of behavior when it comes to sexual misconduct.

Meanwhile, longtime E! News host Catt Sadler quit the network after she says she found out a male counterpart of hers with paid close to double her salary for some time. Sadler writing on her blog that she asked for what she knows she deserves and was denied repeatedly.

And actor Stephen Baldwin is predicting that older brother Alec, impersonator and vocal critic of Donald Trump will be voting to reelect the President. Stephen and avid Trump supporter told the Hollywood Reporter, he believes his brother will vote for Trump after the actor benefits from the new GOP tax bill. When bet on that.

All right, bill many thank billionaires openly lean far to the left, are any of them praising President Trump or the GOP now that major benefits under the new tax cut plan are headed their way? Trace Gallagher is checking in on Silicon Valley tonight, hey Trace.

TRACE GALLAGHER, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Hey, Shannon, you know, even if Silicon Valley does lean left, you can bet a portion of the GOP tax bill is quietly being applauded, the simply the part of the bill that allows major tech companies to bring home the boatloads of money currently being stored overseas to avoid America's aggressive taxation.

In other words, right now, profits are being parked in places like Ireland and Bermuda where the tax rates are low. The problem with hoarding all that money in far-flung destinations is the companies can't put it to work. So, now the Apples and Googles of the world can bring their vast wealth back to the U.S. at a one-time taxation rate of 15.5 percent. That's about 20 points off the current 35 percent rate.

And here is the math. According to several reports, the big five tech companies, we're talking, Apple, Amazon, Facebook, Google, and Microsoft have about $457 billion in overseas subsidiaries. If you bring it all back stateside instead of spending 159 billion in taxes, the tariff is only 70 billion. That's a cool 89 billion in added profit.

And now you know why during the third quarter of this year, the big tech company spent about 25 percent more on lobbying in D.C. than they did during the second quarter. Listen to how the President solved this last week. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: You look at the great companies, Apple and so many others they have billions of dollars overseas that they want to bring back. Now, they're going to be able to bring it back and will be spending that money and they'll be spending that money right here and there will be jobs and lots of other good things.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

GALLAGHER: Of course, it might be the other way run. Might be lots of good things and then jobs because back in 2004, when George W. Bush signed the one-time amnesty for offshore profits, companies reportedly use the money initially for pay increases and bonuses. By the way, Zion Research estimates U.S. companies in general, have about $2.8 trillion in offshore accounts. That's a lot of money that could come home. Shannon.

BREAM: We will watch and see. Trace, thank you very much. Federal investigators looking into Monday's deadly train derailment near Seattle are trying to determine if the engineer was distracted by a second person in the cab, maybe a cell phone or something else. Officials say, the Amtrak train was going 80 miles an hour, just ahead of a 30 mile an hour zone when the cars jump the track and fell on to a busy highway, three people were killed.

Investigators say a conductor in training was in the locomotive with the engineer at the time of the crash. All right, remember those Never Trumpers? What they're saying tonight and why'd it matters so much going forth for the President agenda. And later, the Hezbollah connection to the Obama-Iran deal, and some shady I.T. workers for a top Democratic lawmakers does it all tight together?

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BREAM: We learned today, Minnesota Democrat Senator Al Franken plans to officially resign January 2nd. His appointed replacement, Minnesota Lieutenant Governor Tina Smith, is expected to be sworn in the next day. Franken announced his resignation earlier this month after several women accused him of sexual misconduct.

Well, the Never Trump movement still has adherence within the Republican Party even if they've been a little bit quieter, lately. But after today's passage of the tax cuts and jobs act, is President any closer to winning over his harshest critics within his own Party? Who better to ask, than Rich Lowry, editor of the National Review. Great to have you with us tonight.

RICH LOWRY, EDITOR, NATIONAL REVIEW: Hi, there.

BREAM: OK. So, how would you describe where you were on the President a year ago versus where you are now?

LOWRY: Very skeptical, very worried about what might happen both in terms of the agenda and his behavior in office. He was -- in the campaign, when we talk about he's to spend more money and infrastructure than Hillary Clinton, talked a lot about ripping up trade deals and imposing tariffs, none was that has come to pass first year.

And this week is when I think we really reached the tipping point where we can say it's been a solid first year of accomplishment and conservative accomplishment. He had always had this, unilateral actions. Gorsuch, most important. A lot of unspooling of regulations which is good but they had nothing legislatively.

A big failure on Obamacare. Now, they have a big victory on taxes. Some things that he noted today that are kind of tucked in almost as afterthoughts on this bill that if they're just stand-alone measures, people would have made a big deal of drilling on ANWR, repeal the individual mandate. So, I think you have to give him a pretty good grade on this year.

BREAM: Here's what you said in your pieces, said, "For much of the year, Trump's presidency had seemed to be sound and fury signifying that much besides the welcome ascension of Neil Gorsuch to the Supreme Court. Now, it is sound and fury signifying a discernible shift of American government to the right."

So, do you think even though you may be are giving him credit, obviously for some of this thing that he's done, many within the mainstream media, no way that happens and certainly not the left?

LOWRY: Correct.

BREAM: And even begrudgingly --

LOWRY: Right.

BREAM: I don't think we're going to (INAUDIBLE) that.

LOWRY: Well, one, they're lying about this bill. There is saying it's that tax increase for the middle class based on a projection of what happens in 2027 when all the individual tax cuts expire.

BREAM: And that's the Democrats don't -- if they don't agree to extend them, so, they're going to have some part of them. Is that, that happens because 9-10 years --

LOWRY: Correct, yes, the only way it would happen is if Democrats oppose it.

BREAM: Right.

LOWRY: Which, you know, if they're tone in favor of middle-class tax cuts, they wouldn't. So, that would undermine their talking point there. They want to ignore the economy and look, Trump inherited an economy as much better than what Obama inherited. But right after this election you immediately saw the stock market going up, a surge of business confidence on the expectation that you'd see the deregulation, corporate tax reform, and tax cuts, now, all that's happened.

So, hopefully, that will be an accelerant on the economy and allow Republicans to take credit for the economy and the year ahead. And they need things like that because it does seems as though there's a Democratic wave building just based on animus towards this President.

BREAM: Yes, OK, so, let's talk here some of the things, you mentioned several of these, the ISIS caliphate virtually beaten, the stock market soaring, tax reform passed, out of the Paris climate accord, Jerusalem now designated as Israel's capital we see U.S. recognition. ANWR open for exploration, individual mandate repealed as part of the tax deal, a Justice Gorsuch, unemployment down, and many other things.

So, we've talked a lot about the domestic and the economy which a lot of businesses that you said were acting on the expectations there. But this issue about ISIS is really not getting much attention at all. And not to say that this group is gone away because we know that they full men and, you know, go into other areas and recreate as other things sometimes. But that whole caliphate idea that they were, you know, accelerating just a couple of years ago, it seems at least geographically that's been broken up.

LOWRY: Yes, it's a big deal that we've -- we're over the hump in terms of ISIS and his headed, you know, that the left thinks of him is just a wild- eyed maniac just based on this Twitter feed. They look at this policy in the Middle East, it's been quite cautious. There's been (INAUDIBLE) still tight war against ISIS that has been successful. But you haven't seen any major interventions broaden that release. With North Korea, it's more or less been a status quo approach just with a -- with much more aggressive rhetoric.

No one else would call him little rocket man except for President Trump.

BREAM: No, (INAUDIBLE) --

LOWRY: But there's not in a war's imminent on the Korean Peninsula either. A couple of things where I think, you know, a lot of deregulation and tax cuts, any other Republican would have pushed those things. Where -- I think, we have to thank Navy, these are a couple things only Trump would have done, decertify the Iran deal, pulling out of the Paris accords, declaring Jerusalem the capital of Israel. These were things where he really rand totally against polite opinion, where more conventional Republican might have been more hesitant to do that.

BREAM: Much has happened in this first year, thank you for cataloging a very interesting piece, outlining what's happened. Rich, good to see you.

LOWRY: Thanks very much, Merry Christmas.

BREAM: You too. All right, they worked for former DNC Chairwoman Debbie Wasserman Schultz, could a former I.T. staffers have ties to Hezbollah or other terror groups? We're learning a lot more. We're hearing from a congressman who was demanding that the DOJ probe into this matter, he wants answers, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BREAM: We've got another follow-up tonight to our reporting on an investigation into alleged Obama administration interference in investigations involving the Hezbollah terror group. POLITICO, reports that interference was because of the pending Iran nuclear deal. Tonight, Correspondent Doug McKelway on a possible Hezbollah connection to a scandal we told you about previously here on FOX NEWS @ NIGHT involving I.T. workers with high-level connections to the Democrats.

DOUG MCKELWAY, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: it was called Cars International Aid, CIA for short. A used car dealership in (INAUDIBLE), Virginia. That a lawsuit alleges gave a bad name to used car dealers everywhere. Often bankrupt, the dealership took loans from Hezbollah-linked businessmen in Lebanon.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

LUKE ROSIAK, INVESTIGATIVE REPORTER, THE DAILY CALLER: If got basically fake staffers, they don't have inventory. If someone shows up wanted to buy a car, they go across the street and borrow one --

MCKELWAY: The owner, Imran Awan, the same man who along with four family members was paid $7 million taxpayer dollars to provide I.T. services to 44 Democratic members of Congress, including then, DNC Chairwoman Debbie Wasserman Schultz. During Awan's I.T. work, $120,000 of computer equipment went missing. Imran was arrested on unrelated bank fraud charges at Dallas Airport in July. As he tried to flee to Pakistan. A Daily Caller News Foundation piece posted today found that Awan's used car business had a curious pattern sighted in a recent POLITICO investigation.

ROSIAK: This was a used car dealership, so, are classic money laundering operation that is to use by Hezbollah. Pakistani Intel like I saw I uses them as well. There were reasons, political reasons why even as our nation's security was at stake, prosecutors didn't want to bring charges.

MCKELWAY: The I.T. scandal occurred in the same time frame that POLITICO reports the Obama administration was pulling back on interdiction of Hezbollah drug operations, allegedly so as not to jeopardize the nuclear deal with Iran. Heading up, the Obama administrations organized crime drug enforcement task force at that time was Deputy Attorney General Bruce Ohr.

Ohr was demoted this month after Fox News's James Rosen, reported that he'd concealed meetings with fusion GPS, the company which commissioned the anti-Trump dossier and that Ohr's wife, Nellie works for Fusion.

ROSIAK: There appears to be a cover-up. There's really no other way to look at it. Think about the timing of -- it is shortly before the 2016 election. WikiLeaks has just published the DNC e-mails. How is that not routed to the highest levels of the FBI?

REP. JIM JORDAN (R-OH), HOUSE JUDICIARY COMMITTEE: This at least cries out for a series investigation when you got people who have money problems hanging out with and getting a loan from someone known to hang out with Hezbollah and they have access to the server for dozens and dozens of Democrat elected officials.

MCKELWAY: Late today, Fox News confirmed that the House Oversight Committee will be launching an investigation in the next few days. Five months since Imran Awan's arrested tell us he has yet to be charged with any espionage or terrorism crimes. Preserving the Iran deal is one explanation but there's another.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

Imran Awan downloaded thousands and thousands of Democratic member's personal e-mails on to external hard drives. If spying charges were brought against him, there would be no shortage of black male material that might be released. Law enforcement under pressure from Democrats may be willing to let this sleeping dog lie. Shannon.

BREAM: All right, Doug McKelway, we will see. Well, Imran Awan, most recently employed by a former Chair of the DNC Congresswoman Debbie Wasserman Schultz, also may have exposed congressional information online. He's facing multiple federal charges including bank fraud but also these accusations of allegedly double charging the House for I.T. equipment and many other things now servicing. Republican congressman from Florida, Ron DeSantis, joins us now. And you think there may be a national security risk here.

REP. RON DESANTIS (R-FL), HOUSE JUDICIARY COMMITTEE: Well, if you look at, this is clearly some type of money laundering operation when you have that CIA car dealership which really didn't have cars and they had a fake staff --

BREAM: And that was the name they gave it, CIA.

DESANTIS: Right.

BREAM: People know what we're talking about, not a CIA car dealership.

DESANTIS: Exactly. Well, but I mean, I think people, look at that, they probably doing that for a reason, our -- potentially we're doing of reason. So, you have a situation, they're all making the whole family. Awan, his wife, brothers, they're making like 160 grand a year --

BREAM: Each.

DESANTIS: -- suppose we do this, I.T. work. So, that's equivalent to the highest ranking staffers and Congress chiefs of staff. This guys, Awan was a little older, his -- one of his brothers was like in his early 20's, and working at McDonald's part-time. So, this whole thing just right there states. Then, what happened to all this money? And really there's no good explanation for it other than this is money that's being sent overseas, they had deep relationships with people on Pakistan -- we travel there. The first $100,000 for the car dealership was given to them by an Iraqi with ties to Hezbollah. So, what was going on in the House? Why didn't anyone see what these guys were up to? What were they doing with the data that they were had access to few members of Congress? And where was this money going, it wasn't going for a furious purpose?

BREAM: Yes, because their allegations that they were logging into accounts of members they weren't working for. They were never hired to work for on the Hill. If you read this piece in The Daily Caller by Luke Rosiak, it talks about these car dealerships, these businesses that don't seem to make much sense. The financial trail is very fuzzy, the explanation are very strange. Here is what Luke said today about what this looks like when you look at the story of this guys.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ROSIAK: This was a used car dealership, so, are classic money laundering operation that is to use by Hezbollah. Pakistani Intel like I saw I uses them as well.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BREAM: So, you think that may have been what was happening here, and I know you're pressing the DOJ for some answers or at least for them to take a different look at this.

DESANTIS: Right, because Awan is under indictment now but not for anything national security related.

BREAM: Right.

DESANTIS: There's an investigation into the Democrats in the -- within the House, in the House Admin Committee. Which is important but that's not going to get into national security implications. So, I think we need to do that and I do think we need more answers than we been given.

BREAM: I want to ask you too because we have talked you and I a lot about Israel, this move that the President primly has announced about recognizing Jerusalem as the capital, the United Nations not too happy. The Security Council held a vote earlier this week, the U.S., the only once to be until on seen it against this, there'll be a vote again tomorrow. Here is what the President has said about what may go down at the U.N. tomorrow.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: I like the message Nikki sent yesterday at the United Nations. For all of these nations that take our money and then they vote against us at the Security Council. Or they vote against us potentially at the assembly. They take hundreds and millions of dollars and even billions of dollars and then they vote against us. Well, we're watching these votes. Let them vote against us, we'll save a lot. We don't care.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BREAM: Do you think he's going to cut off the money? Some of it, either to the U.N. or certainly this company -- or country because you know, their votes are not going to be close.

DESANTIS: I love it. I mean, the first in 2016, the U.N. had of 24 resolutions, 20 of them were against Israel. It is one tiny little country, only Democracy in the Middle East, and oh, by the way, the only Jewish State in the world. And the U.N. is pathologically focused on singling them out. And I -- we've seen enough of it. I'm glad the President say, enough with this.

His decision to recognize Jerusalem was the right one. It was not necessarily an easy one because other Presidents have promised it and they reneged on their promise. He kept his promise and I think that was the right decision and I look forward to Nikki Haley standing up for the U.S., the President's decision and standing by our friend Israel.

BREAM: She says we'll be taking names tomorrow. Meanwhile, we know we've got a busy week trying to work on getting the government funded. Keep us updated on that for things we're making time in the meantime --

DESANTIS: Good to see you, Merry Christmas.

BREAM: And Merry Christmas to you. All right, coming up, an incredible story of survival and striving of a badly wounded marine. Stick around.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BREAM: Tonight, a salute to Marine Kyle Carpenter, who was awarded the Medal of Honor for throwing himself on an exploding grenade, saving the life of the fellow Marine. Despite suffering the loss of his right eye and a collapsed lung, Carpenter came home determined to complete his college education.

He graduated Monday from the University of South Carolina. Carpenter called it one of the most incredible moments since he woke up in the hospital and realized he had a second chance of life. We can never thank him enough and congratulations. Most watched, most trusted, and most grateful you spent the evening with us. Good night from Washington, I'm Shannon Bream.

END

urn:contentItem:5R79-8V31-JB20-G0Y3-00000-00$1.5 Trillion Tax Cut Bill, Taxpayers Expected To See Paycheck Changes In February; Trump On Tax Bill, Results Will Speak For Themselves; Chain Migration, Trump Pushes Congress To Get Tough On Immigration2017-12-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:07:03ZLexisNexisFOX NEWS @ NIGHT11:00 PM ESTMatt Schlapp, Chris Kofinis122001cb.259$1.5 Trillion Tax Cut Bill, Taxpayers Expected To See Paycheck Changes In February; Trump On Tax Bill, Results Will Speak For Themselves; Chain Migration, Trump Pushes Congress To Get Tough On ImmigrationShannon Bream, Ed Henry, Ellison Barber, Laura Ingraham

LAURA INGRAHAM, FOX NEWS CHANNEL HOST: To Chuck Schumer and Nancy Pelosi, through all of this, I'm reminded of this great holiday classic. Do you guys know that bumbles bounce right now? Shannon Bream, take it away.

SHANNON BREAM, FOX NEWS CHANNEL HOST: We got serious things to talk about Laura. How can I not laugh at that? It's goofy. All right, thank you very much. Here's what's coming up on our show tonight.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Merry Christmas America.

BREAM: ObamaCare's individual mandate repealed, $1.5 trillion in tax cuts, companies already responding, so why are critics saying bah humbug?

REP. JACKIE SPEIER (D), CALIFORNIA: A lump of coal into your Christmas stocking.

SEN. CHUCK SCHUMER (D-NY), SENATE MINORITY LEADER: The economy is not going to take off.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: The ugliest display of pigs at the

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Are you living in a fantasy world?

BREAM: Will downplaying historic tax cuts backfire on the President's critics? We'll debate.

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: It's always a lot of fun when you win.

BREAM: Plus, the Obama administration, the former Head of the DNC, Hezbollah, and some shady I.T. workers on Capitol Hill and a reported possible connection.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: This was a classic money laundering operation.

BREAM: We investigate another bombshell report with Congressman Ron DeSantis. And he once said that President Trump was a menace to conservatism. Rich Lowry explains why some never Trumpers are now partying with the President.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BREAM: Hello and welcome to FOX NEWS @NIGHT, I'm Shannon Bream in Washington. New tonight, as the most sweeping changes to the tax code in more than 30 years make their way to the President's desk, we're learning about new challenges to the $1.5 trillion tax cuts and new indications it's already having a positive impact. First those challenges. Blue states like California, New York, and New Jersey are already looking at taking legal action trying to stop tax reform before it becomes law. The bill hits those states hardest with high incomes, high property values and high state and local taxes. For example, Bloomberg reporting tonight about this effect on Wall Street, "One trader sipping a Bloody Mary on a morning flight to somewhere more tropical said he's going to stop registering as a Republican." New Jersey Governor-elect Democrat Phil Murphy says "everything is on the table including challenging the constitutionality of the bill.

PHIL MURPHY (D), GOVERNOR-ELECT, NEW JERSEY: It's many thousands of dollars Carl and this is an awful bill for America, it's an awful day for America and it certainly is an awful bill for New Jersey. We're going to have to fight back.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BREAM: Well, they're going to have to move fast because here are the pluses. One sign, taxpayers across the nation will likely see the first changes to their tax and their pay holding -- paycheck holdings as soon as February. Also, several major companies announcing their workers will see some of the tax windfalls from cutting the corporate tax rate from 21 percent to -- from 35 percent including big bonuses for workers in some cases. Democrats calling it all a public relations stunt, "a fraction of the bounty" as one media report puts it. Things are moving fast here in Washington so we've got team coverage tonight. Ellison Barber has the latest on the next big fight which is keeping the government open past the Friday deadline. And Chief National Correspondent Ed Henry is covering the development since the President and Republicans celebrated their legislative victory. So, Ed, we begin with you. Good evening.

ED HENRY, FOX NEWS CHANNEL, CHIEF NATIONAL CORRESPONDENT: Well, Shannon, I haven't seen any Bloody Marys around here at the White House tonight but I can tell you remembering the campaign, President Trump promised that Americans would get tired of all the winning. And while to be sure, he has a long way to go before he can say that he's enacted a large share of his agenda. He is claiming momentum tonight that just a few short weeks or even months ago would've seemed impossible.

Take a look at this pep rally he had on the south lawn in addition to the last cabinet meeting, the last cabinet meeting of the year where he was touting various successes. He had Republican Leaders like Paul Ryan and Mitch McConnell on board. Remember, after the failure of repeal and replace, the President mocked McConnell on Twitter and left the door open to another Republican taking the Majority Leader post. Tonight here's the big picture is tax cuts that could supercharge an economy taking off. Thanks in part to massive cuts the government regulations have already taken place. The tax bill also includes ANWR. That means opening the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to energy exploration. That's decades in the making. If it we're standalone bill, it would be massive in and of itself. There's also a major initiative on health care.

They eliminated the individual mandate in ObamaCare. It is not repeal and replace but it is a major pushing back on the signature domestic achievement of the President's predecessor. The President also at that cabinet meeting today touting the fact that ISIS is on the run, something that he promised in the campaign to much skepticism, also touting the confirmation of Supreme Court Justice Neil Gorsuch plus a record number of Circuit Court Judicial Nominees that have been confirmed. Not a single Democrat though voted for this tax package. So if it succeeds, they'll have a hard time explaining it in the midterm elections. But Democrats have been consistent about charging this will cost too much money. It will add a lot to the debt, and perhaps the most prominent talking point of all has been that the corporate tax cut they say will not trickle down the workers. Listen to Chuck Schumer.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SCHUMER: At&T, a big American company, a fine American company. They are tax rate over the last ten years was a mere eight percent and they cut 80,000 jobs. That one statistic belies all of this trickle-down bunk.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

HENRY: Yet, just a couple of hours later, At&T announced it will pay yes, a special $1,000 bonus to more than200,000 of their employees trickling down. Today Boeing announced $300 million in employee-related investments. Fifth Third Bank Corp. announced plans to raise its minimum hourly wage for all employees. All employees to $15 and distribute yes a one-time bonus of $1000 because of the tax cut. Wells Fargo saying its pay rate will go up to $15 and they're pledging next year $400 million in charitable contributions as well. All reasons why some of the President's advisor tonight are telling me they want to pivot out of this victory on tax cuts to infrastructure, immigration information reform, other big issues. And there's pro-Trump non-profit group America first policies is now planning $1 million T.V. ad blitz that will start on Christmas Day, but in fact, they're giving FOX NEWS @NIGHT a first look. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Thank you for cutting my taxes.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Thank you for fixing our economy.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Thank you for keeping my family safe.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Thank you for putting America first.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Thank you for supporting Israel.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: As veterans, thank you for reminding us to stand for our National Anthem.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Thank you, President Trump.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Thank you, President Trump, for letting us a Merry Christmas again.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

HENRY: And we mention that riff with Senator Mitch McConnell, they were all smiles in the Oval Office today. The Kentucky Senator bringing yes, a Louisville slugger from his home state to give to the President after this tax cut victory. Clearly, they are trying to pivot out of this to other victories. Although there are still a lot of challenges heading into the New Year for this President including yes, the Special Counsel investigation by Robert Mueller, Shannon.

BREAM: All right. What a difference a big legislative win makes. Ed Henry at the White House, thank you so much, Ed. All right, as President Trump and the GOP celebrate a big win on the tax bill, they do face a very new challenge getting Democrats on board with a funding measure to keep the government going past midnight Friday. The clock is ticking and loudly. Ellison Barber joins us now with more on that looming battle. Good evening Ellison.

ELLISON BARBER, FOX NEWS CHANNEL CORRESPONDENT: Good evening Shannon. Republican Leaders and the White House say a shutdown is absolutely not going to happen. Behind the scenes though, rank-and-file Republicans do not seem as optimistic. Utah Congressman Chris Stewart told one of our producers that this, the continuing resolution, would never be as easy as party leaders expected. He also said, "we need to do a better job multitasking." Republicans met at 5:00 this evening and talked for an hour, trying to find a way to move ahead.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Do you have a plan?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I think there's a number of different factors. There's you know, do you do separate bills, do you put them all together? You know, the coalition of supplemental versus 702 reauthorizations.

REP. DAVE BRAT (R), VIRGINIA: There are some disparate needs in terms of defense (INAUDIBLE) right? I want get defense right.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I'm optimistic we can get there. We're not there yet.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARBER: Republicans tested the waters among their party tonight with two options. One, an interim bill that funds the government at current levels through mid-January and includes defense anomalies or bumps that increase spending, renewal of the controversial domestic spying FISA program, and some assistance for children's health insurance. The second, a stand-alone $81 billion supplemental disaster spending bill for hurricane damage in places Puerto Rico and Texas and the wildfires in California. Some say Republicans waited too long to do all of this and spent too much time focusing on the tax bill.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SCHUMER: The bottom line is we haven't even seen anything. They're so busy with the tax proposal that we haven't even seen a proposal.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARBER: House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi sent this note to Democrats earlier today urging a No vote on the C.R. It says in part, "Democrats want to see funding for opioids, veterans pensions, and support for the DREAM Act which would clarify the legal status for hundreds of thousands of immigrants." She also writes "unless we see respect for our values and priorities, we continue to urge a strong No on the continuing resolution." Now here's what some House Democrats said last week.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JOSEPH CROWLEY (D), NEW YORK: The question really is as to whether we will have that leverage. We believe when we are discussing a spending package for next year that they will need our votes to pass it. And when they do, they will need to talk to us about what our priorities are which includes DACA, which includes CHIP, which includes community health sentence, which includes opioids.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARBER: Republican celebrated a major political win this afternoon, a little doubt about that. But now the question seems to be will the Republicans in Congress negate that win in less than 48 hours by failing to prevent a shutdown and sending thousands of government workers home for Christmas without a paycheck. Shannon?

urn:contentItem:5TF2-W711-F021-631M-00000-00$1m on art? Computer billionaire says no;Tech titans spurn cultural philanthropy, the V&A director said last week. True, but they are trying to solve world problems instead2018-10-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:07:03ZLexisNexisNEWSVersion:1$1m on art? Computer billionaire says noTech titans spurn cultural philanthropy, the V&A director said last week. True, but they are trying to solve world problems insteadJohn Arlidge

Moneymakers with little interest in cultural philanthropy or art collecting. That's what Tristram Hunt, the director of the Victoria and Albert Museum, called tech billionaires last week. The former Labour MP told the Cliveden Literary Festival that the richest entrepreneurs in Silicon Valley and Europe were not following the gilded lead set by the billionaire businessmen of the past. "Their passions in terms of philanthropy are often not connected to cultural institutions," he said. Oliver Barker, the European chairman of Sotheby's auctioneers, who was also at the festival, added that Silicon Valley's elite had little interest in or knowledge of the art market.

Hunt and Barker have a point - up to a point. They're wrong that techies don't care for art. Paul Allen, the Microsoft co-founder who is worth $20.5bn (£15.7bn), once showed me round his vast Bond-villain-style home on Mercer Island, 15 minutes' drive from central Seattle, and pointed out works by Monet, Picasso, Renoir and Lichtenstein. He has exhibited many of them to the public at Seattle Art Fair, which he sponsors. He has also founded and funds a museum of pop culture in his hometown, where you can sometimes find some of his other prized possessions: Yoda's cane from Star Wars, Paul Newman's hat from Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid, the black Everlast boxing gloves Robert De Niro wore in Raging Bull.

Larry Ellison, co-founder of the software giant Oracle, has a large collection of Japanese art. Sixty-four works were exhibited at San Francisco's Asian Art Museum in 2013. Evan Spiegel, co-founder and chief executive of the social media company Snap, owns several works by the contemporary painter Wyatt Mills and commissioned him to paint a mural outside Snap's headquarters in Venice, California - though the two did go to high school together.

But Hunt and Barker are right that very few of the big-tech bosses support public arts and culture with "billanthropy". Look around the main art galleries, theatres and concert halls in San Francisco, Los Angeles, New York, London and Paris and you'll find plenty of big names on big buildings - Sainsbury, Getty, Geffen, BP, JP Morgan, Deutsche Bank, Credit Suisse, Guggenheim, Dorfman, Pritzker, Blavatnik, Clore, Duffield - but they're from the worlds of retail, industry, finance and entertainment. The only big arts venue named after a Silicon Valley titan is the Steve Jobs Theatre, and that's tucked away for Apple's private use in its new $5bn headquarters in Cupertino, California.

"It's definitely a cultural shift," says Rohan Silva, the creator of London's Tech City initiative, and a former adviser to David Cameron. Why are tech titans so reluctant to show their artistic side?

Many of the founders of the biggest tech companies do not really see the need to do and be seen to do good works at all, since they think that's already what they do in their day job. Goldman Sachs may need to soften its "blood-sucking vampire squid" image by sponsoring the arts, but tech firms argue they're doing "God's work". Google is making the world's information available to everyone for free. What could be evil about that? Facebook is connecting the world, with some 2.2bn people using its platform regularly. "They don't feel ashamed of their business, nor feel they have to civilise themselves or their reputation by putting their name on a new wing or a gallery," says Silva.

Jeff Dauber, a former Apple executive who has a private collection of 325 works of mainly contemporary art at his home in San Francisco, says age is an issue. Many of the new establishment are billionaires, but they are also very young, too young to appreciate art or be confident enough in their judgment to invest either for themselves or on behalf of their company. "The tech boom has brought a lot of money in, but if you didn't grow up seeing art, spending half a million dollars on one piece can be really intimidating," he says. The Facebook co-founder Mark Zuckerberg, worth $60bn, is 34.

Advisers to entrepreneurs say many are suspicious of the arts because so many galleries and museums are publicly funded by government and city councils. "The default techie mindset is: we're new and different. We're disruptors. We're free from the shackles of the past, especially regulation and government that stifle innovation," says one leading West Coast executive who works with some of the wealthiest company bosses, so asked not to be named. "They see the world solely through a private-sector lens."

The techies have side projects, of course. Every self-respecting billionaire needs one. But these tend to be moon shots that chime with their desire to solve practical problems and change the world, not cultural hit-and-hopes. Larry Page, Google co-founder, is personally funding two secretive flying car start-ups: Zee Aero and Kitty Hawk. With his fellow Google founder, Sergey Brin, he is experimenting with putting giant solar-powered wi-fi devices on balloons to bring the internet to remote places on the planet. Soon, people in Burkina Faso will be able to watch Donald Trump mash-up videos on YouTube, too.

Brin owns the $80m 240ft superyacht Dragonfly, but he's also spending $100m on an "air yacht", a giant airship that will bring humanitarian aid to the world's poor. Brin and Page's holding company Alphabet is pouring $750m into a "longevity lab" that is researching how we can stay young indefinitely. Ellison also funds "life extension" research. "Death makes me very angry," says Ellison, as if it were just another practical problem, such as traffic congestion, that brain power, research and technology can solve. Live for ever? Click here.

Jeff Bezos, Amazon's founder, who is   the world's richest man worth $157bn, is investing $1bn a year in Blue Origin, his space exploration company, which has already launched several rockets into orbit that have successfully returned to Earth. His goal is to move mining and manufacturing off Earth and into space to safeguard our environment.

Elon Musk also has his own pocket rocket that he wants to use to help mankind to conquer Mars, which is where some investors in his electric car firm, Tesla, might like to send him after its recent share-price slump. Musk is also backing Open AI, a non-profit organisation that aims to promote and develop "safe" artificial intelligence. He's worried that smart machines could all too easily turn against their creators - us - Terminator-style.

When Peter Thiel, PayPal co-founder and early investor in Facebook, is not using his $2.5bn fortune to settle petty scores - he bankrupted media website Gawker because it wrote nasty things about him - he is partial to crafting a survival strategy for himself and his fellow techno-libertarians. He's buying up chunks of New Zealand, a country he sees as a haven of peace and stability blissfully devoid of the roiling backlash against the global elite. Just in case that doesn't work, he is flirting with creating floating offshore city states on man-made islands in international waters.

None of this is to say that techies don't give to charity. They do. But when they do, they prefer to act in line with their business instincts. That means doing something innovative that has not been tried before, ideally in an area where they can measure the benefits of their largesse with hard data. You can't calibrate the impact of splurging on art, other than perhaps by totting up the personal pleasure it gives the buyer. Data is more precise than Degas.

The Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, which was launched in 2000 with $20bn and whose endowments now total more than $50bn, focuses on global health and education but in a market-oriented way. Rather than helping to cure cancer, which the largest pharmaceutical companies are already trying to do, it focuses on diseases that kill far more people worldwide but attract less interest from big pharma because most of the victims live in developing countries so there is little money to be made from a cure. The best example is malaria, which Gates and his wife say they are on the way to conquering.

Mark Zuckerberg and his wife, Priscilla Chan, have the Chan Zuckerberg Initiative. It funds medical research and makes investments in science and education. The couple have pledged an initial $3bn, and 99% of Zuckerberg's Facebook shares over their lifetimes, worth $45bn at the time of its launch. Their most ambitious stated goal is to help cure, manage or prevent all disease by the year 2100.

Bezos recently pledged $2bn to the Bezos Day One Fund, an initiative to create a network of free Montessori-based pre-schools in needy areas in the US. The Bezos family has also given $35m to the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Centre and $33m for scholarships for undocumented migrants in the US.

There's an unwieldy name for this kind of giving: philanthrocapitalism. Garry Jenkins, law professor at Minnesota University, describes it as "directive, controlling, metric-focused and business- oriented". It sounds anathema to Hunt, but Silva welcomes it as a breath of fresh air.

"It's great that the West Coast entrepreneurs are not simply mimicking the approach of the past: make a ton of money, feel bad about how you made it, salve your conscience and launder your reputation by slapping your name on a gallery or two and sit back and wait for your gong," he says. "You might think it's nerdy to scan the horizon for problems to solve and then set yourself wildly ambitious goals supported with billions of dollars, but what's more important: ridding the world of killer diseases or a new statue for Tristram Hunt?"

Just in case that doesn't work, he is flirting with creating floating offshore city states on man-made islands in international waters.

That means doing something innovative that has not been tried before, ideally in an area where they can measure the benefits of their largesse with hard data. You can't calibrate the impact of splurging on art, other than perhaps by totting up the personal pleasure it gives the buyer. Data is more precise than Degas.

The Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, which was launched in 2000 with $20bn and whose endowments now total more than $50bn, focuses on global health and education but in a market-oriented way. Rather than helping to cure cancer, which the largest pharmaceutical companies are already trying to do, it focuses on diseases that kill far more people worldwide but attract less interest from big pharma because most of the victims live in developing countries so there is little money to be made from a cure. The best example is malaria, which Gates and his wife say they are on the way to conquering.

Mark Zuckerberg and his wife, Priscilla Chan, have the Chan Zuckerberg Initiative. It funds medical research and makes investments in science and education. The couple have pledged an initial $3bn, and 99% of Zuckerberg's Facebook shares over their lifetimes, worth $45bn at the time of its launch. Their most ambitious stated goal is to help cure, manage or prevent all disease by the year 2100.

Bezos recently pledged $2bn to the Bezos Day One Fund, an initiative to create a network of free Montessoribased pre-schools in needy areas in the US. The Bezos family has also given $35m to the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Centre and $33m for scholarships for undocumented migrants in the US.

There's an unwieldy name for this kind of giving: philanthrocapitalism. Garry Jenkins, law professor at Minnesota University, describes it as "directive, controlling, metric-focused and businessoriented". It sounds anathema to Hunt, but Silva welcomes it as a breath of fresh air.

"It's great that the West Coast entrepreneurs are not simply mimicking the approach of the past: make a ton of money, feel bad about how you made it, salve your conscience and launder your reputation by slapping your name on a gallery or two and sit back and wait for your gong," he says. COMPUTER BILLIONAIRE SAYS NOTech titans spurn cultural philanthropy, the V&A director said last week. True, but they are trying to solve world problems insteadJOHN ARLIDGE

Moneymakers with little interest in cultural philanthropy or art collecting. That's what Tristram Hunt, the director of the Victoria and Albert Museum, called tech billionaires last week. The former Labour MP told the Cliveden Literary Festival that the richest entrepreneurs in Silicon Valley and Europe were not following the gilded lead set by the billionaire businessmen of the past. "Their passions in terms of philanthropy are often not connected to cultural institutions," he said. Oliver Barker, the European chairman of Sotheby's auctioneers, who was also at the festival, added that Silicon Valley's elite had little interest in or knowledge of the art market.

Hunt and Barker have a point - up to a point. They're wrong that techies don't care for art. Paul Allen, the Microsoft co-founder who is worth $20.5bn ((EURO)17.7bn), once showed me round his vast Bond-villain-style home on Mercer Island, 15 minutes' drive from central Seattle, and pointed out works by Monet, Picasso, Renoir and Lichtenstein. He has exhibited many of them to the public at Seattle Art Fair, which he sponsors. He has also founded and funds a museum of pop culture in his hometown, where you can sometimes find some of his other prized possessions: Yoda's cane from Star Wars, Paul Newman's hat from Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid, the black Everlast boxing gloves Robert De Niro wore in Raging Bull.

Larry Ellison, co-founder of the software giant Oracle, has a large collection of Japanese art. Sixtyfour works were exhibited at San Francisco's Asian Art Museum in 2013. Evan Spiegel, co-founder and chief executive of the social media company Snap, owns several works by the contemporary painter Wyatt Mills and commissioned him to paint a mural outside Snap's headquarters in Venice, California - though the two did go to high school together.

But Hunt and Barker are right that very few of the big-tech bosses support public arts and culture with "billanthropy". Look around the main art galleries, theatres and concert halls in San Francisco, Los Angeles, New York, London and Paris and you'll find plenty of big names on big buildings - Sainsbury, Getty, Geffen, BP, JP Morgan, Deutsche Bank, Credit Suisse, Guggenheim, Dorfman, Pritzker, Blavatnik, Clore, Duffield - but they're from the worlds of retail, industry, finance and entertainment. The only big arts venue named after a Silicon Valley titan is the Steve Jobs Theatre, and that's tucked away for Apple's private use in its new $5bn headquarters in Cupertino, California.

"It's definitely a cultural shift," says Rohan Silva, the creator of Lon-don's Tech City initiative, and a former adviser to David Cameron. Why are tech titans so reluctant to show their artistic side? Many of the founders of the biggest tech companies do not really see the need to do and be seen to do good works at all, since they think that's already what they do in their day job. Goldman Sachs may need to soften its "blood-sucking vampire squid" image by sponsoring the arts, but tech firms argue they're doing "God's work". Google is making the world's information available to everyone for free. What could be evil about that? Facebook is connecting the world, with some 2.2bn people using its platform regularly. "They don't feel ashamed of their business, nor feel they have to civilise themselves or their reputation by putting their name on a new wing or a gallery," says Silva.

Jeff Dauber, a former Apple executive who has a private collection of 325 works of mainly contemporary art at his home in San Francisco, says age is an issue.

Many of the new establishment are billionaires, but they are also very young, too young to appreciate art or be confident enough in their judgment to invest either for themselves or on behalf of their company. "The tech boom has brought a lot of money in, but if you didn't grow up seeing art, spending half a million dollars on one piece can be really intimidating," he says. The Facebook co-founder Mark Zuckerberg, worth $60bn, is 34.

Advisers to entrepreneurs say many are suspicious of the arts because so many galleries and museums are publicly funded by government and city councils. "The default techie mindset is: we're new and different. We're disruptors. We're free from the shackles of the past, especially regulation and government that stifle innovation," says one leading West Coast executive who works with some of the wealthiest company bosses, so asked not to be named. "They see the world solely through a private-sector lens."

The techies have side projects, of course. Every self-respecting billionaire needs one. But these tend to be moon shots that chime with their desire to solve practical problems and change the world, not cultural hit-and-hopes. Larry Page, Google co-founder, is personally funding two secretive flying car start-ups: Zee Aero and Kitty Hawk. With his fellow Google founder, Sergey Brin, he is experimenting with putting giant solar-powered wi-fi devices on balloons to bring the internet to remote places on the planet.

Soon, people in Burkina Faso will be able to watch Donald Trump mash-up videos on YouTube, too.

Brin owns the $80m 240ft superyacht Dragonfly, but he's also spending $100m on an "air yacht", a giant airship that will bring humanitarian aid to the world's poor. Brin and Page's holding company Alphabet is pouring $750m into a "longevity lab" that is researching how we can stay young indefinitely. Ellison also funds "life extension" research. "Death makes me very angry," says Ellison, as if it were just another practical problem, such as traffic congestion, that brain power, research and technology can solve. Live for ever? Click here.

Jeff Bezos, Amazon's founder, who is the world's richest man worth $157bn, is investing $1bn a year in Blue Origin, his space exploration company, which has already launched several rockets into orbit that have successfully returned to Earth. His goal is to move mining and manufacturing off Earth and into space to safeguard our environment.

Elon Musk also has his own pocket rocket that he wants to use to help mankind to conquer Mars, which is where some investors in his electric car firm, Tesla, might like to send him after its recent share-price slump. Musk is also backing Open AI, a non-profit organisation that aims to promote and develop "safe" artificial intelligence. He's worried that smart machines could all too easily turn against their creators - us - Terminator-style.

When Peter Thiel, PayPal co-founder and early investor in Facebook, is not using his $2.5bn fortune to settle petty scores - he bankrupted media website Gawker because it wrote nasty things about him - he is partial to crafting a survival strategy for himself and his fellow techno-libertarians. None of this is to say that techies don't give to charity. They do. But when they do, they prefer to act in line with their business instincts. You can't calibrate the impact of splurging on art, other than perhaps by totting up the personal pleasure it gives the buyer. Data is more precise than Degas. The Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, which was launched in 2000 with $20bn and whose endowments now total more than $50bn, focuses on global health and education but in a market-oriented way. Rather than helping to cure cancer, which the largest pharmaceutical companies are already trying to do, it focuses on diseases that kill far more people worldwide but attract less interest from big pharma because most of the victims live in developing countries so there is little money to be made from a cure. The best example is malaria, which Gates and his wife say they are on the way to conquering.

The couple have pledged an initial $3bn, and 99% of Zuckerberg's Facebook shares over their lifetimes, worth $45bn at the time of its launch. Their most ambitious stated goal is to help cure, manage or prevent all disease by the year 2100.

Bezos recently pledged $2bn to the Bezos Day One Fund, an initiative to create a network of free Montessoribased pre-schools in needy areas in the US. The Bezos family has also given $35m to the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Centre and $33m for scholarships for undocumented migrants in the US.
